items.title: _‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üî¥ Critical_
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_

**Consider `ON DELETE SET NULL` or separate audit retention policy.**

`ON DELETE CASCADE` on `tip_split_id` means audit entries are deleted when the parent split is deleted. This defeats the audit trail purpose‚Äîyou lose the history of deleted splits.


<details>
<summary>Suggested alternatives</summary>

**Option 1: Use SET NULL to preserve history**
```diff
-  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
+  tip_split_id UUID REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE SET NULL,
```

**Option 2: Remove FK constraint for audit independence**
```diff
-  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
+  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL, -- No FK; audit persists after split deletion
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In supabase/migrations/20260103000000_add_tip_split_audit.sql around lines 6‚Äì14,
the tip_split_id FK uses ON DELETE CASCADE which removes audit rows when a
tip_split is deleted; change the schema so audit entries are preserved: make
tip_split_id nullable and replace ON DELETE CASCADE with ON DELETE SET NULL (or
remove the FK entirely if you prefer audit independence) and document/implement
a separate retention policy for purging old audit rows as needed.
```

</details>

<!-- fingerprinting:phantom:medusa:ocelot -->

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment by CodeRabbit -->

_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_

**Consider `ON DELETE SET NULL` or separate audit retention policy.**

`ON DELETE CASCADE` on `tip_split_id` means audit entries are deleted when the parent split is deleted. This defeats the audit trail purpose‚Äîyou lose the history of deleted splits.


<details>
<summary>Suggested alternatives</summary>

**Option 1: Use SET NULL to preserve history**
```diff
-  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
+  tip_split_id UUID REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE SET NULL,
```

**Option 2: Remove FK constraint for audit independence**
```diff
-  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
+  tip_split_id UUID NOT NULL, -- No FK; audit persists after split deletion
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In supabase/migrations/20260103000000_add_tip_split_audit.sql around lines 6‚Äì14,
the tip_split_id FK uses ON DELETE CASCADE which removes audit rows when a
tip_split is deleted; change the schema so audit entries are preserved: make
tip_split_id nullable and replace ON DELETE CASCADE with ON DELETE SET NULL (or
remove the FK entirely if you prefer audit independence) and document/implement
a separate retention policy for purging old audit rows as needed.
```

</details>

items.title: _‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_

**tip_split_audit schema: consider including `restaurant_id` for data isolation**

`tip_split_audit` currently has `tip_split_id` and a FK to `tip_splits` but no `restaurant_id`. That means:
- UI code can‚Äôt follow the repo guideline ‚Äúalways filter Supabase queries by `restaurant_id`‚Äù on this table directly.
- Isolation must come entirely from RLS (joining through `tip_splits`) or from always querying by `tip_split_id`, which is more fragile for future usages (e.g., listing audits across splits for a restaurant).



I‚Äôd strongly consider adding a `restaurant_id` column (with an index) kept in sync via trigger, or exposing a view/RPC that enforces restaurant scoping, so frontend code can keep using the standard `{ restaurant_id }` filter pattern.<!-- no TS diff suggested since the source of truth is the SQL schema -->

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In src/integrations/supabase/types.ts around lines 5703 to 5743, the
tip_split_audit table type lacks a restaurant_id field which prevents following
the repo guideline to always filter Supabase queries by restaurant_id; add a
restaurant_id:string | null (or string if non-nullable) to Row, and
corresponding optional restaurant_id in Insert and Update types, then update the
SQL schema to add a restaurant_id column with an index and a DB trigger (or a
materialized/regular view or RPC) to keep it in sync from tip_splits on
insert/update so frontend can safely filter by { restaurant_id } and RLS can use
that column directly.
```

</details>

items.title: _‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üî¥ Critical_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üî¥ Critical_

**RLS policies fail for deleted splits‚Äîaudit entries become invisible.**

Both policies join `tip_splits` on `tip_split_id`, but after a split is deleted, `tip_split_id` becomes `NULL` (due to `ON DELETE SET NULL`). The `JOIN` will fail for those audit entries, making them invisible to managers who should be able to view the complete audit trail.



<details>
<summary>üîé Proposed fix</summary>

Use `split_reference` with a LEFT JOIN or subquery to look up the restaurant_id, or store `restaurant_id` directly in the audit table:

**Option 1: Add restaurant_id to audit table (recommended)**

Update the table creation:
```diff
 CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS tip_split_audit (
   id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
   tip_split_id UUID REFERENCES tip_splits(id) ON DELETE SET NULL,
   split_reference UUID NOT NULL,
+  restaurant_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES restaurants(id),
   action TEXT NOT NULL CHECK (action IN ('created', 'approved', 'reopened', 'modified', 'archived', 'deleted')),
```

Update the trigger to populate it:
```diff
   IF TG_OP = 'INSERT' THEN
     INSERT INTO tip_split_audit (tip_split_id, split_reference, action, changed_by, restaurant_id)
-    VALUES (NEW.id, NEW.id, 'created', NEW.created_by);
+    VALUES (NEW.id, NEW.id, 'created', NEW.created_by, NEW.restaurant_id);
```

Update policies to use restaurant_id directly:
```diff
 CREATE POLICY "Managers can view tip split audit"
   ON tip_split_audit FOR SELECT
   USING (
     EXISTS (
-      SELECT 1 FROM tip_splits
-      JOIN user_restaurants ON user_restaurants.restaurant_id = tip_splits.restaurant_id
-      WHERE tip_splits.id = tip_split_audit.tip_split_id
+      SELECT 1 FROM user_restaurants
+      WHERE user_restaurants.restaurant_id = tip_split_audit.restaurant_id
       AND user_restaurants.user_id = auth.uid()
       AND user_restaurants.role IN ('owner', 'manager')
     )
   );
```

**Option 2: Use LEFT JOIN with split_reference**
```sql
CREATE POLICY "Managers can view tip split audit"
  ON tip_split_audit FOR SELECT
  USING (
    EXISTS (
      SELECT 1 FROM tip_splits
      JOIN user_restaurants ON user_restaurants.restaurant_id = tip_splits.restaurant_id
      WHERE tip_splits.id = COALESCE(tip_split_audit.tip_split_id, tip_split_audit.split_reference)
      AND user_restaurants.user_id = auth.uid()
      AND user_restaurants.role IN ('owner', 'manager')
    )
  );
```
</details>


> Committable suggestion skipped: line range outside the PR's diff.

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In supabase/migrations/20260103000000_add_tip_split_audit.sql around lines
27-52, the RLS policies join tip_splits on tip_split_id which breaks when
tip_splits are deleted (tip_split_id becomes NULL), hiding audit rows; fix by
either (preferred) adding restaurant_id to tip_split_audit, updating the trigger
to populate restaurant_id when creating audit rows, and changing the policies to
check user_restaurants.restaurant_id = tip_split_audit.restaurant_id for both
SELECT and INSERT, or (alternative) change the policy predicate to resolve
restaurant_id via COALESCE(tip_split_audit.tip_split_id,
tip_split_audit.split_reference) with a LEFT JOIN on tip_splits (or a subquery)
so deleted splits still map to a restaurant for RLS checks.
```

</details>

items.title: _‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü† Major_

**Handle NULL from auth.uid() in audit trail.**

The trigger uses `auth.uid()` for `changed_by` in reopen (line 86), modify (line 98), and delete (line 109) operations. However, `auth.uid()` returns `NULL` when called outside an authenticated session (e.g., from background jobs, scheduled tasks, or cascading triggers). This could result in audit entries without attribution, defeating the audit trail's accountability purpose.



<details>
<summary>üîé Recommended approach</summary>

**Option 1: Require authentication (recommended for user-initiated actions)**

Document that these operations must occur within an authenticated session and add assertions:

```diff
   -- Detect reopen (approved ‚Üí draft)
   IF OLD.status = 'approved' AND NEW.status = 'draft' THEN
+    IF auth.uid() IS NULL THEN
+      RAISE EXCEPTION 'Reopen requires authenticated user';
+    END IF;
     INSERT INTO tip_split_audit (tip_split_id, split_reference, action, changed_by, reason)
     VALUES (
       NEW.id,
       NEW.id, 
       'reopened', 
       auth.uid(),
       'Manager reopened for editing'
     );
   END IF;
```

**Option 2: Allow NULL for system-initiated changes**

Make `changed_by` nullable in the schema and handle NULL gracefully:

```diff
-  changed_by UUID REFERENCES auth.users(id),
+  changed_by UUID REFERENCES auth.users(id), -- NULL for system-initiated changes
```

Update trigger to distinguish system vs. user changes:
```sql
changed_by := COALESCE(auth.uid(), '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000'::uuid); -- system user
```
</details>


Also applies to: 91-101, 106-111

items.title: _‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü° Minor_
items.body:
_‚ö†Ô∏è Potential issue_ | _üü° Minor_

**Consider timezone consistency for tip_date derivation.**

The trigger uses `AT TIME ZONE 'UTC'` when deriving `tip_date` from `recorded_at`, but the initial backfill at line 22 uses a simple cast `recorded_at::date` without timezone conversion. This could cause inconsistencies between existing and new records if `recorded_at` values are stored with timezone offsets.


<details>
<summary>Suggested fix for consistency</summary>

```diff
 -- Populate tip_date from recorded_at for existing rows
 UPDATE employee_tips
-SET tip_date = recorded_at::date
+SET tip_date = (recorded_at AT TIME ZONE 'UTC')::date
 WHERE tip_date IS NULL;
```
</details>

<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

lines 35 to 44, the trigger derives tip_date using (recorded_at AT TIME ZONE
'UTC')::date while the backfill earlier (around line 22) uses recorded_at::date,
which can produce inconsistent dates when recorded_at has timezone offsets; make
them consistent by updating the backfill to set tip_date = (recorded_at AT TIME
ZONE 'UTC')::date (or alternatively remove the AT TIME ZONE usage in the trigger
and change both to recorded_at::date) so both existing and future records derive

**Test doesn't verify the documented scenario.**

The test name and JSDoc promise to verify tip double-counting prevention when "both employee declarations and manager-approved splits exist for the same date," but the implementation only verifies that the Tips page loads. No tip data (employee_tips or tip_splits) is created, and no double-counting prevention logic is exercised or verified.

To properly test this scenario, the test should:
1. Seed employee tip declarations for a specific date
2. Create manager-approved splits for the same date  
3. Navigate to payroll or aggregation UI
4. Verify tips are counted only once (not doubled)

The `__seedIncomeStatement` helper documented in `tests/helpers/e2e-supabase.ts` can seed tip data. Consider using it or creating tip splits directly via helpers to exercise the actual double-counting prevention logic.
